metadata.case_name: Appellant v. First Respondent (Hoshangabad Constituency Election)

facts.text: Appellant and respondents 1 to 5 nominated for election to House of the People from Hoshangabad Constituency, Madhya Pradesh.
Respondents 4 and 5 withdrew, leaving contest among others.
At polling, appellant secured 65,201 votes, first respondent 65,375 votes, declared duly elected by Returning Officer.
In polling stations Nos. 316 and 317 at Sobhapur, voters for House of the People given ballot papers with brown bar (for State Assembly) instead of green bar (for Parliament) under Rule 28.
Total such votes: 443, of which 62 for appellant, 301 for first respondent, remaining for others.

Appellant filed Election Petition No. 180 of 1952 to set aside election, alleging 301 votes for first respondent liable to rejection under Rule 47(1)(c) for lacking prescribed distinguishing mark, materially affecting result.
First respondent contested petition, pleaded Rule 47 directory, defect cured by Election Commission.

First respondent filed recrimination petition under s.97 RPA 1951, alleging at polling station No.299 Malkajra and No.371 Bammangaon, wrong ballot papers issued for House of People, wrongly rejected, would give him 117 more votes than appellant.
Election Tribunal: Majority held Rule 47(1)(c) mandatory, 301 votes should be rejected; unanimous that result not materially affected; dismissed petition. Third member held rule directory.
Appellant moved High Court of Nagpur under Arts.226/227 for certiorari to quash Tribunal decision.
High Court (Sinha CJ, Mudholkar, Bhutt JJ): Differed; majority dismissed petition, granted certificate under Art.132(1).
Returning Officer at Hoshangabad obtained Election Commission approval post-polling but pre-counting for including wrong ballot papers.

legal_issues.text: Whether High Courts have jurisdiction under Art.226 to issue writs against decisions of Election Tribunals, given Art.329(b).
Whether writ of certiorari can issue against functus officio Election Tribunal.
Whether Rule 47(1)(c) of RPA 1951 Rules is mandatory or directory.
Whether result of election materially affected under s.100(2)(c) RPA by improper reception of 301 votes lacking distinguishing mark.
Scope of enquiry under s.100(2)(c) and effect of recrimination under s.97.

petitioner_arguments.text: 301 ballot papers for first respondent liable to rejection under mandatory Rule 47(1)(c) for wrong distinguishing mark; exclusion would make appellant elected; result materially affected.
Tribunal erred in considering extraneous matters like polling officer mistake under Rule 23 for s.100(2)(c) enquiry; error of law/jurisdiction apparent on face of record warranting certiorari.
High Court has jurisdiction under Arts.226/227 despite Art.329(b), as post-Tribunal decision not 'calling in question election'.

respondent_arguments.text: Rule 47(1)(c) directory, not mandatory; Returning Officer rightly accepted votes; defect cured by Election Commission approval.
Art.329(b) bars High Court jurisdiction under Art.226 as it calls in question election; Tribunal functus officio, no writ possible.
Under s.100(2)(c), Tribunal could consider polling officer mistake (Rule 23 breach), voter intention; result not materially affected; recrimination shows appellant's election also invalid.

court_reasoning.text: Art.329(b) bars initiation of proceedings questioning election except by election petition; post-Tribunal decisions subject to Art.226 supervisory jurisdiction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Art.329(b) satisfied once election petition filed; writs competent against Tribunal decisions.

court_reasoning.text: Certiorari to quash directed against record, not tribunal; issueable even if functus officio, to custodian of record (e.g., District Judge u/s.103 RPA).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Certiorari demolishes offending order; continued existence of tribunal not necessary.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 47(1)(c) mandatory, as 'shall be rejected'; consistent with other sub-rules (a,b,d); no degrees of compliance possible.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Wrong mark ballot papers liable to rejection despite polling officer mistake.

court_reasoning.text: Election Commission approval post-polling cannot validate; mark must be prescribed pre-poll under Rule 28.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot condone defect in specified ballot papers; uniform mark required.

court_reasoning.text: Under s.100(2)(c), Tribunal cannot count rejected votes under Rule 47 to ascertain voter intention; result means on valid votes per Rule 48; Tribunal exceeded by considering Rule 23 breach beyond.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Error of law apparent on face of record; s.97 recrimination shows no valid election.

court_reasoning.text: Certiorari issues for jurisdictional error, natural justice violation, or manifest legal error on face of record.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tribunal's s.100(2)(c) decision erroneous, warranting quashing.

holdings.text: High Courts have jurisdiction under Art.226 to issue certiorari against Election Tribunal decisions notwithstanding Art.329(b).
Certiorari to quash competent against functus officio tribunal.
Rule 47(1)(c) mandatory; 301 ballot papers rightly held rejectable by Tribunal majority.
Tribunal erred in holding result not materially affected under s.100(2)(c) by considering extraneous Rule 23 matters; no valid election due to recrimination.

precedents_cited.case_name: N. P. Ponnuswami v. Returning Officer, Namakkal Constituency
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.329(b) covers entire election process; bars pre-Tribunal challenges.
Art.329(b) does not bar post-Tribunal appeals u/Art.136.

precedents_cited.case_name: T. C. Basappa v. T. Nagappa
precedents_cited.relevance: Nature of certiorari: supervisory, quashes without substituting; not appellate.
Art.227 superintendence over tribunals judicial and administrative.
Mandatory rejection for identification marks; polling errors not always vitiate.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rex v. Northumberland Compensation Appeal Tribunal Ex parte Shaw
precedents_cited.relevance: Certiorari for error of law apparent on face of record.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Jurisdiction of High Courts for writs/superintendence over Tribunals; bar on questioning elections except by petition.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951 (Act No. XLIII of 1951)
statutes_cited.relevance: Recrimination; setting aside elections for improper reception/void votes/material effect; rejection of ballot papers without distinguishing mark; records custody.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court and Tribunal decisions quashed by certiorari under Art.226; election of first respondent set aside under Art.227; no valid election due to defects on both sides; Election Commission to hold fresh election.
outcome.relief_granted: Election set aside; fresh poll directed.

key_quotes.text: "Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution no election shall be called in question except by an election petition..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Art.329(b) limits to initiation; post-petition remedies available.

key_quotes.text: The word 'shall' in Rule 47(1)(c) construed as mandatory, as no degrees of compliance in rejection.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects directory argument; votes without mark invalid.

key_quotes.text: "Certiorari will also be issued when the Court or Tribunal acts illegally... or there is an error apparent on the face of the record."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Grounds for certiorari; applies to Tribunal's s.100(2)(c) error.
